As the title suggests Chinatown is full of nick knack shops full of souvenirs and perfume. It is a great place to buy souvenirs and also to get a reasonably priced and hearty meal.
You can also get bargain jewelry if you are prepared to negotiate. My wife picked up a couple of bargains whilst we were there.
They also have tailors who will custom make articles of clothing for you as well as some amazing hand painted paintings and hand carved wooden souvenirs.
When you in Singapore take a wander through Chinatown you will find plenty of great eateries as well as pick up a bargain or two.
You can get there by bus from anywhere in Singapore and it only costs you $1.60 Singaporean dollars to get there.
Interesting, bustling place. Nearest you get to old Singapore. Indian temple in Pagoda street worth visiting. Food very usually very good and to sit and watch the world go by is fun.

REVIEW_TITLE: Cheap shopping in nice & clean environment
REVIEW_BODY: As the name says, it's a paradise for cheap shopping & shoppers. Gift items are available for as low as S$1.00. This place is worth for souveniers & gift items as it will not burn hole in yr pockets & you will get quality products also. Food & drink options are also available. Area is very neat, clean, well maintained & connected with bus routes & MRT.

The best time to visit CHINA TOWN is after 5 pm. It really becomes lively in evening. Try the best of Singapore Cuisine on the Food Street. There are a number of shops for buying souvenirs. If you are going by MRT then take the exit towards Pagoda street and you will reach exactly in the middle of the activities . You also opt to visit China Town Heritage centre which is located near the MRT exit.
Budha Tooth relic temple is a short walk away from there on South Bridge Road.

This the place where one can see the old heritage of Singapore , the buildings are beautiful and the heritage is well protected. Very cheap shopping as compared to even mustafa. The place is well decorated with red lanterns and traditional dresses, food is very typical Chinese and bargain also

Great place to shop, Peoples Park Complex. The hawker centre on the first floor across the road from Peoples Park is awesome, it runs along Smith St, there would have to be at least 800 stalls that sell every type of food you could want, all about SG$3:50 a plate and a beer about SG$6:30 a large bottle. Great place for lunch but a word of advice, remember where your table is because you can take ages to find it again.
The streets are well lit up in the evenings making it quite lively and colourful. There are several eateries all around offering local cuisine are very affordable prices

Lots to see and do in this warren of alleys and market stalls. There are lots of stalls selling the same thing, but just as many selling unique items. Look for those bargains. Haggling a price isn't really embraced in this place, but there is always room for making polite suggestions as to an alternate price. I wouldn't recommend using any of the tailors/dressmakers, their prices are not cheap.

I would recommend coming here at night with friends. Grab some late night Chinese food and drinks under the red ballon lights. Very cool spot to hang out. I went during the day, and I felt an extreme amount of materialism and pressure to buy things.. not my style.

Great to wander around and so many food places that have great food. Lots of small stalls and cheap souvenirs. Great for a cheap day out if you have a family with children wishing to spend a dollar. No harassment for buying except maybe some of the food places.

When buying souvenirs, this is one of the best place to get them. Prices can be haggled and sellers are willing to give you extra for free when buying in bulk. The small chinese food stalls provide good variety of snacks while shopping. Just dont go when its raining as most stalls are outdoor

~ People's Park Complex - A large gathering place for Chinese from China, lots of shops, money changers and authentic China food stalls. Very China oriented.
~ Cross the road, a tourist hub with streets full of stalls selling various souvenirs and eateries.
~ Clean, well organise and convenient. Busy street on a Sunday morning. Good atmosphere.

REVIEW_TITLE: Buy nice items with cheaper price
REVIEW_BODY: I'm from India got little confused with the shop names,but we can buy many items with very. Cheap price
Our hostel is located right in Chinatown. Easy access to food stalls, souvenir shops and the MRT. A great place to visit.

REVIEW_TITLE: Only Vegetarian eating place in Chinatown..Good for Pure Vegetarians.
REVIEW_BODY:
Though there are many only-vegetarians eateries in Little India, there is this place in China Town , Chan Chan Heng eating place , that serves organic only-veg food. The ambience is no frills, non AC, small tables, but the food is tasty and the best part is pure vegetarians who do not wish to eat in outlets serving both veg and non veg, this is a big relief.
Location: Temple Street, Chinatown,Singapore.
We went here for souvenirs shops,and bargains. Lots of stalls and lots of interesting things to buy to bring back home. Lots of Chinese restaurants,nice food.
Big contrast between the skyscrapers in modern Singapore and this old market place where you find yourself thrown back in time;
You will find the cheapest singapore goods here. 36 pieces of keychains for 10 dollars. ALSO here you have the most delicious chili crab and the cheapest too.
One of the cleanest China towns in the world. Great place to buy nick-knacks, curios and other take-aways
Cheap Shopping area with most of the Chinese products available with nice food court with tasty food. But at the end we can buy lot of cheap gifts, Chocolates etc here

Fantastic place for your souviners. A bit haggling is required for the best bargins.You can have a suit made in a few hours. Such a vibrant place to be .Everyone speaks English so there's know problems. Would definitely recommend a visit here.

REVIEW_TITLE: Fantastic way to spend a few hours
REVIEW_BODY: The colours and smells of Singapore are never more overwhelming than during a walk around Chinatown. Lots of stalls selling food, trinkets and treats... No self respecting tourist could go to Singapore and not enjoy Chinatown... Loved it!!!

i like the chines temple there . Things found in china town was ok not that impressive. I had an hour time to look around . Loved the architecture around that place then shopping. shopped few key chains and fridge magnet there .
Must go place in SG. At night, it's so crowded with people. The presents are also plenty to choose. Let's feel the different styles of Chinatown!

Singapore China Town just like other major city's china town. Here you can shopping variety of merchandise at good bargain price. Next to this place is Clark Quay and Singapore River. It is interesting to explore it.

REVIEW_TITLE: Good place to shop on budget
REVIEW_BODY: We took a mrt from kitchner road to reach here and i believe within 150 dollars lots of shopping was done. A good place.
One can see many heritage restored buildings here. This is not far from Little India. Actually no place is far in Singapore!
Bright lights, lots of look at and great food... Bustling with food markets, touristy bits and local delights it's a must see and do!
Last night we had a Chinatown walking tour, quite insightful but not super great. We ate at yum Cha which was quite ok., plenty of food shops to visit and eat as well as shopping
Had heaps of fun exploring and eating here. Always a bargain to be had. A bustling experience worth the time but make sure you have a couple of spare hours

Chinatown area is very interesting. You can get around to see how the locals are, try out their food. This area also have quite a number of supermarket, but it also have the more traditional market. Must go in Singapore.
who want gifts,foods,temples,hotels you must come to Chinatown you'll find these. แหล่งรวมทุกอย่าง ของฝากแต่ละร้านไม่ต่างกันมากเท่าไหร่ เดินได้ มีจุดท่องเที่ยวใกล้ๆเยอะ แต่หน้าร้อน ร้อนมากกกกกก

Take the MRT to Chinatown and you come up in the middle of it. Clean toilets are located at this station. The streets are brightly decorated with red lanterns and a variety of shops ranging from cheap souvenirs to more expensive goods are located on either side. Food street has a good range of little cafes but for a more authentic experience visit the Hawker Centre. We were having a quick visit so cooled off with an ice cream concoction that contained coloured balls that popped in your mouth. Great fun for a four year old. Venture further from the main streets and visit the malls where the locals shop. Climb the steps to the bridge for great views. Also look up when walking to appreciate the architecture of the houses with brightly coloured shutters. Take the time to visit the Indian temple and also the magnificent Buddha Tooth Relic Temple.
This place is a budget shopper's delight. We bought a lot of souvenirs for our friends and relatives without causing a big hole in our pocket.

REVIEW_TITLE: Interesting mixture of religions and food
REVIEW_BODY: Chinatown is a place worth visiting in Singapore. There are a wide varieties of food and a deep culture of the early immigrants in Singapore (Chinese and Indian). There are a few places worth visiting like the Buddha Tooth Relic Temple, The Indian Temple and the Chinatown Heritage Centre. There are plenty of food to choose from and many souvenirs to buy as well.

Chinatown is full of cheap little markets where you can grab a cheap souvenirs . I've been twice only for that reason . It's not overly large , a hour or two is enough time is see everything . Great central location

I'd rather shop here than in other place. It has a straight walk at Pagoda Street and from the MRT exit until you meet the main road you can find many shops with affordable price! I guess it depends on what event is happening. I went here on August 2015 during SG independence day and the price for keychain is S$10 for 24 or 36 if I'm not mistaken. But on May 2016 visit I buy S$10 for 42!!!
This is one of the better China towns. Everything is so cheap! Food is top and the whole place buzzing. Spent a lot of time here and will high on list for return visits.

Enjoyed our visit here. Great place to buy many, many Singapore souvenirs. The prices are ok too for the kind of quality products you get there. Loved the varied collection. Good medicine shops. Many eateries. Will definitely visit here again on our next trip to Singapore. Better to leave the kids back though, they may not enjoy the small street walking or the crowd.
Good market with cheap and quality products. Chinese culture, products and colourful decoration with food street are all characteristics of this town.

Both the markets (where you can buy cheap knock off anything designer)and the variety of restaurants makes China Town another don't miss it. You can come here every day for a week and find something new.
we went here for dinner and had the most amazing chilli crab. It's quite a bustling place in the evening, I loved the food court.

Wonderful atmosphere in the evenings! Had many visits to Chinatown for the amazingly tasty and CHEAP food on offer. Picked up good herbal medicines and souvenirs too. Don't leave Singapore without a visit to Chinatown!

Chinatown is a place everyone should go to when visiting Singapore, the food is good , the beer is cheap and it's a good way to spend a few hours wandering around looking at all the stalls and buying the odd singlet or what ever takes your fancy !
We will find a lots of chinese culture here with so many souvenir stores. Spend 2 - 3 hours is not enough. We will have so many option for having breakfast, lunch or dinner here. Awesome !!
The night markets are alive with atmosphere and bright lights Easily assessable by train / taxi Cheap souvenirs / clothing and food areas
Found nearly all my souvenirs to take home in Chinatown. The cleanest streets I've seen! Lovely atmosphere. Will visit again.
Noisy, hot, loads of cheap tat but just wonderful. As close as you'll come to the real old Singapore. Some great places to eat and some great antique shops which are, however, pricey.

REVIEW_TITLE: "Bullcart Water" literally, name of Chinatown Singapopre
REVIEW_BODY: The heart of commerce where modern Singapore started, the place where Chinese immigrants first settled when they came. Today, there are more China Chinese shops and restaurants and a place to taste many cheap & delicious local delights. This is a place to be during the Chinese New Year period (Jan - Feb every year), where you can buy Chinese food goodies and enjoy street decorations & lightnings to immense in the festive atmosphere. Don't miss the Buddha Relic Temple nearby when you are in Chinatown.
We had a great day walking the streets and shopping for our souvenirs. Heaps to choose from. Even got my daughters iPhone repaired for a good price. Food is a plenty. Worth a visit.
Good shopping street. Lot of 2 dollar shops to get your souvenirs. Can be visited for your shopping needs. Typical Chinese street with some food options too.

We lunched at a local establishment on Chilly Crab and beer. It was affordable and awesome! Chinatown was hot and crowded with many tourist offerings. It was a vey interesting place. We visited several antique shops along the main street and made a small purchase. A fun and interesting place to visit.
regular market. not so good shops but a place to wander and visit. you can get variety of gift items and clothes.

If you have been to one Chinatown you have been to all. We did have fun strolling through the stalls in Chinatown. Ate at the food stalls, picked up shopping Singapore bags - USD 10 for 5 bags and had an evening of fun.

Im not sure if the prices are cheap, but I took a walk around the place and you can buy gifts, there are many shops which offers very different items. Have options for food but I did not have any there.

I love to walking around this area. Buy things and eat things, haha. But now Chinatown is not safe like before, so many money pocket there, as my bad experience at MRT station, a pretty lady open my backpack use her pen. She thought i put my wallet or handphone there as many Singaporean did. But i still lucky anyway because i always put my wallet and handphone not there. Anyway.. i still recommend you to visit Chinatown and dont forget to try Lee Che Guan BBQ Pork, Mango Ice at Temple street, Foo Chow Fish ball at Seow Choon Hua food stall, Steam fish and Soya Sauce Chicken at Chinatown Food Court and many many more...
Chinatown is lively, full of tacky but amusing knick knack shops and there are some decent meals to be had and pretty interesting Temples in the neighborhood. Must see for tourists.
We got dinner nearly every day in such area. Good food, suitable price, big choice for 20 s$ maxi. I recommend the 630 cl fresh Tiger beer at 6 S$ after a thirsty day !!!
This was a interesting little place, our teenagers loved it as it was great value for money. Even I picked up some little gifts. You really cant go to singapore and not visit.
A vibrant area full of colour and life. Lots of places to eat and buy gifts. Absolutely buzzing with life!
Those who want to buy some good souvenirs and some electronic goods, this is a place to visit. You will feel as if you are in China and has some good places for food as well.
I was there in china New Year there was festival very crowed but nice place and can buy pore gold...

REVIEW_TITLE: The tooth relic temple and bargain goods
REVIEW_BODY: In our tour the main attraction at the China Town was the Buddha tooth relic temple which was a very peaceful place in the middle of busy streets. The shops were mostly selling ornamental items which were providing good bargains for bulk purchases.

REVIEW_TITLE: Good place to eat on budget
REVIEW_BODY: Singapore is very expensive. head to Chinatown if you want to eat for reasonable price. There are several food markets, where you can have a street dish for 1-2£.

Brilliant bustling market where you can shop for hours for all the tack you wish, make sure to haggle though and walk away if the price isn't right. Busy the Buddhist temple also, I didn't see it but a family member did and loved it. Maybe not for kids in the temple though.

Only a few minutes on the mtr travel system from marina bay, this place was full of character, lots of markets and excellent places to eat, and cheaply compared to that of marina bay. People like all of Singapore were very friendly and accommodating. For smokers this area is a lot more relaxed about where one can smoke. The older generation were playing board games day and night anywhere really that had benches which added to the charisma of Chinatown.

We came around 12 noon and the place is already bustling with shoppers but still spacious enough to look around. There are lots of shops offering varieties of souvenirs from gem stones to t-shirts, slippers, key chains, ref magnet, coasters, clothes and bags. Good quality T-shirts (Singapore print) are quite expensive ranging from 15 to 30 SGD. We noticed anything related to clothes are quite expensive while souvenirs like ref magnet, Chinese slippers, beverage coaster, etc… cost 3 for 10 SGD or 3 for 1 SGD depending on the type of product. There’s a shop near the Temple where they sell bags with Singapore design costing 5 pcs for 10 SGD; for most shops it cost 4 pcs for 10 SGD. I suggest to check all the shops first before buying souvenirs if you are on tight budget. Stall owners are nice and helpful. Luckily we didn't encounter owners pressing us to buy stuffs; they mostly stand there on the look out for any customers who requires assistance. As for the food, there are lots of stalls and we chose the one near the stairs. Delicious and cheap. Chicken noodles/rice cost around 4 or 5 SGD. They also give free soup and there’s fruit shakes to counter the heat. Definitely my place for buying souvenirs.
We loved China Town! Lots of fun souvenirs & good prices & some wonderful food courts & restaurants! Definitely worth a visit!
I like to shop alot most specially the stores beside the temple... Food is great most specially near the maxwel place...ohhhh the chicken rice is soooooòo good
Good to visit but in truth no different to many Chinese communities in the UK. Sights and sounds are much the same but a good place to try food.

REVIEW_TITLE: Great for the hussle and bustle
REVIEW_BODY: Really worth a trip to China town, there are two temples a Hindu and a Buddha temple both are extremely interesting. Then you can shop in the street markets and eat at the food stalls

REVIEW_TITLE: A look at the Singapore past before the boom .
REVIEW_BODY:
The Singapore for the international businessman or foreign tourist is but a very small vignette of the city/state. Chinatown is more reflective of the real Singapore working class. Crowded, noisy, bustling with a working class population and the less affluent and aged. A place to visit ? YES! See how people work to improve their lot, the enterprlsing nature of the residents, the electric atmosphere of vendors competing to empty your wallet.
For shoppers, there are many bargains to be found, but you have to search for the good stuff, a lot of fun ! Not to be missed if you are touring.

P.S. The food is the real deal !! Don't be put off by the no frills atmosphere of the food courts, its real life.
My husband and I spent hours in Chinatown just hanging out. One of the best Chinatowns we have been to!
Spent 1-2 hours shopping here while on a Singapore trip in February. It is a good place to shop for cheap, novelty souvenirs and grab some snacks while experiencing some unique architecture.

Had a wander in Chinatowm as part of SIA hop on/off bus trip. Interesting sights (we elected not to visit the numerous temples but you could if you wanted too). Street food was nice (plenty of options) and cheap. Definitely worth a visit.

Went there with my kids on the TRAM exit "Chinatown" Not big one.
The food there didn't seem very clean so I walked across the street and eaten at a mall.
3 floors, no waw deals, I got foot massage and got the H. OTA there.
C U AROUND

Wow! What can I say! This is one of the best Chinatowns that I have visited. Clean and orderly, with plenty of places for good food and good shopping. Definitely go to Maxwell Center for some incredible food!

We enjoyed Chinatown and did most of our souvenir shopping here. I've been here at night and it is better then. There is a shop on the right as you exit the MRT station (Exit A) where you can buy $1 bottles of water, cold and refreshing after shopping! Beware of the camera shops here. I was looking for a cheap lens and the first camera shop tried to sell me one for $550 then dropped his price down to $225 - I got the same lens for $89 elsewhere. Most of the shopowners were lovely and helpful and ready to bargain. Others not so much, even giving up a sale for the sake of a $1!!!
Lot of market place at Chinatown. Easy to access by metro. Cheap place to by materials from china, souveniers and that kind of stuff.
But then again I like China town no matter the country. In Singapore also go to Little India, Holland village , Arab St, the Malaysian corner and the Philipino market....love Singapore.

REVIEW_TITLE: Best place for real chinese food
REVIEW_BODY:
This place was real china town 40 years back, then it become a local place to visit during chinese new year. But recent influx of china people here to work and as tourist, this place has transformed into a little bit of real china. The street food (which is totally safe to eat) sold are from mainland china, and all different parts of china, such as the duck neck, potato biscuits, cold dish, meat buns. And then there are the singapore popiah, kueh tu tu, muah jee... all nice tasting from my point of view.
But my favourite reason for visiting this place is to change money, the rates are the best so far, ask around shops and bargain to your best rate, don't change at the very first shop unless you are changing less than USD 100.
Lastly, the annual chinese new year decorations around feb every year is a must see. If you want to eat the real good and cheap local food, go to the food center on the second floor near the buddha tooth relic temple, it's where the local eat usual lunch as well.
I've been in China-Town a few times and I always enjoy it. Sure the things they sell is nothing special but the atmosphere is nice.

Strangely enough for Chinatown, you do not enjoy as cheap a stuff as you think. True you get the usual Chinese rubbish cheaply but anything else can be more expensive than you think.
You do enjoy the usual Chinatown paraphernalia and food stalks but the shopping streets where their lined with stalls are usually the most busy area.
I understand the fake goods stalls are usually more prevalent in the night time but we went in the daytime so I am unable to comment on that aspect.

REVIEW_TITLE: More like a flea market than "town"
REVIEW_BODY: Easy to get to via the underground. There are many shops and smaller stores and although it is like a "flea market" the shops are larger and more formal. Almost everything is sold from cheaper knock offs to genuine antique asian stuff. Some of the jewellery stores have some well priced and genuine stuff and you can find almost anything you are looking for. There are many food stalls and although we did not eat there, it all seemed quite well priced.

The place is good but nothing special in chinatown. You will find only things for Chinese people but to have a walk to discover the culture is nice. in bugis street you will find more things to buy and good price.

REVIEW_TITLE: Guess you need to have it on the list
REVIEW_BODY: Well it's a spot full of tourists and every other store offers the typical souvenirs. Go to the temple and the information center to explore a bit of the history of this place.

What a great way to spend the morning and early afternoon. Take a look into a guided tour. We chose Wei (indiesingapore) and we were left with a greater appreciation for this area and a want to head back later in out stay to take a deeper look into the suggested tips Wei gave us. Lots of great local AUTHENTIC food here and tons of shopping too.

The place is pretty safe but just like in any other place always be wary of your wallets and valuables. Shop for souvenirs ranging from 3pcs for SG$5 or 10. Don't settle for the first store. Always ask as there might be other stores that offer the same item for cheaper price. We bought key chains for SG$1 each only to find another store that sells 42pcs of keychain for SG$10! Oh, the place can be a bit muddy when it rains.

We really enjoyed our multiple visits to Chinatown. There is a real diversity here- in food, shopping and people. I don't think you can go wrong with the restaurants- everything was great and reasonably priced. Worth the visit

Our hotel is located very close to Chinatown where we can walk about 10 minutes or 1 station by train. There are so many local foods where you can choose there. Highly recommend street foods. The price are little expensive but we like all the favors. There is the local markets near by where we were quite enjoy buying some souvenirs and there are so many options. The white bag with different design of Singapore prints are very great quality and it's just 2 dollars each woww, I bought about 10 bags. Highly recommend this place.
Stayed in Chinatown. So much happening in this little pocket. Walk and experience the uniqueness that is Singapore's Chinatown

REVIEW_TITLE: Frantastic place to visit, easy transport on MRT from all of Singapore
REVIEW_BODY: Great area to visit, prices are much cheaper here and the locals are very helpful and friendly. A shop to you drop location, have fun.

Whenever we want to look for a cheap place to eat, then Chinatown is the place. We ordered Singapore chili crab and it never let us down. There is also a lot of cheap souvenirs like keychains, bags and other items. Walk a lot and be surprised.

be prepared to walk... a lot! you end up going from one street to the next to the next, then down a lane. I lost track of how many blocks we ended up walking, but found so many interesting things to look at
Great place to go for small gifts for friends and family back home and cheap clothes. Friendly shop assistants and a very good shopping experience.

REVIEW_TITLE: This is a really great place to explore
REVIEW_BODY: Chinatown is a really great place to explore. It has something for everyone; history, architecture, shopping and amazing food (probably the best hawker center in Singapore). The only downside is that more than half the market is full of tourist rubbish.

China town brings you the feel of real China in Singapore.The moment you step out of China Town MRT station ,you would feel as you though had been transported to China.The hawker centres are reasonable and offer tasty delicacies.China town street gives options for cheap street shopping,and cheap Singapore souvenirs.
Plenty of different types of shopping and varying cultures. Great places to eat. Amazing architecture.

Rows and rows of products made in.....? China ofcourse. If your looking for cheap souvenirs and food, mixed with some history, definitely make a stop here. Make sure not to spend too much time here though, as the rest of The magnificent city awaits.

REVIEW_TITLE: Great place to understand chinese culture
REVIEW_BODY: Do visit the chinatown heritage centre which showcase the old singapore. At chinatown, there are many stalls selling souvenirs with good price.

From shophouses to restaurants, from dry goods to foods - feel, smell and taste China. And, the area is clean. You can also see some religious places like a Hindu and Buddhist temples. Don't forget to buy some souvenirs and taste the local cuisine at Smith Street.

Fab place to grab the obligatory souvenirs. Plenty of delicious street food to try also. Very clean and absolutely no hassle from market traders. Excellent prices for authentic name brand perfumes also with tax rebate form provided so take along your passport. Some great little bars with really cheap beer (hard to find in Singapore!!).
Singapore China town is very clean and tidy, the food is great and feels very inviting. a must see when visiting singapore
if you want to buy souvenir for another you can come here at night it have many many place to sell in and important! Chinese food in here really delicious have to taste it!

What are the 3 most used word in the world? Made in China! So in the heart of Singapore could not miss charm and bustle specific Chinese. Temple and shopping , a lot of people , joy , everything for everyone . Not to be missed .

As I was walking through the markets, I was very disappointed to be conned into entering a store/ then being told that I should purchase a suit. When I told the store owner that I wasn't interested - he then insisted that I go and visit his wife who has a jewellery store (a few stores down). She was so pushy/ it was just totally awkward & she didn't want to take No for an answer. I ended up walking out...... I wonder how many unsuspecting tourists have fallen into their trap & felt obliged to purchase goods that they never wanted or intended to buy.
Best place to do souvenir shopping..cheaper than Bugis street. Lots of option in $ 2 or $ 3 ..keychain, sunglasses, watches, pens, bags

REVIEW_TITLE: Awesome place must visit,if in singapore !!
REVIEW_BODY: Chinatown will be the most happening and fun place, especially in feb, as it is the chinese years time....the roads/streets shops, resturants, all lit up and decorated, must visit ,,,if in singapore !!!

Came here ust after Chinese New Year so a lot of the decorations are still up. Beautiful Buddhist Temple within the heart of this bustling area. The usual tourist tat on sale but the food at the Hawker centres is great and excellent value.

REVIEW_TITLE: Always love to pop in, when in Singapore
REVIEW_BODY: Love to eat, shop or just browse here. My sisters loved it here and had each done a fair bit of shopping here. I myself, am happy just see what's new to sell here. Loved their Singapore printed t-shirts. It's always worth a look.

REVIEW_TITLE: Go for the food and atmosphere
REVIEW_BODY: We went to Chinatown at night and during the day. It is so much better at night. It didn't hurt that it was Chinese New Year so it was beautifully decorated. The food is cheap and delicious. The beer is a bit pricey but that is the way it is in Singapore. The stalls are all brightly coloured and very inviting. Don't believe what you hear....you can haggle on some higher priced items. Also there is free wifi throughout Chinatown. Definitely worth a visit.
Shops galore although many things are just cheap knock offs. You have to bargain. I mentioned to my husband that I had NEVER seen so many Chinese Restarnats lined up like that - not even in China.

REVIEW_TITLE: Busk in the mood of festivities
REVIEW_BODY:
Like all Chinatowns around the world, this is the place to find a piece of Chinese culture and food. Good for leisurely walk if you don't mind the heat. You can find great food at the multi-storey hawker centre (ask for that). This haven lies great Singapore food of all sorts at totally affordable pricing.
If you'd prefer proper dining environment in air con comfort. Yum cha restaurant nearby serves good tim sum.
The place comes totally alive during lunar new year, needless to say.

Our Experience: We took the MRT and reached there very conveniently.. Great place to buy souvenirs.. Walkable distance from Maxwell Food center.. although it was closed on that day so we found another hawker centre while walking back from there towards the MRT..

TIPS
1. Its alright to visit here even when it rains because all the shops outside the MRT are quite well sheltered from the rain.
2. Key chains and magnets are abundant and cheap so visit all shops before u finalize ur purchase.
3. Chinese lanterns are available and they look gorgeous so if u want some to decorate ur home make sure u bargain and get them.
4. Maxwell food centre was closed or something so we walked back and came across this nice food street on Smith Street which offers a variety of cuisines.

Visited China Town many times during my visits to Singapore. it is a must for all visitors. The Peoples Palace has a great atmosphere as well as very good prices. The Market outside is great with lots of bargains and bric-a-brac.

Chinatown is a great place for chilling out. There are so many food stalls, souvenir shops, medical shops, and hotel/hostel here. Also don't forget to visit Sri Mahariamman and Buddha Tooth Relic temple. They're close to Chinatown area.

REVIEW_TITLE: Nice to visit but not much going on in the evening
REVIEW_BODY: We went here around 8.30 - 9.30pm and it was quiet but colourful with the lights. There are a variety of shops selling all sorts from food to tourist tatt (many of these) and we didn't find it as good as we'd expected. However, we're pleased we went; it's good to see the area and as we went with friend who are locals we were given an insight into the foods they buy along with seeing their interaction with the stall holders.
We were but lost while searching for a veg restaurant, but when we accidentally got in we just loved the place. Beautiful and old. Mix culture and definitely great culture mix
The restaurants shops and the atmosphere is fantastic they also have great Jewelly shops and massage salons it's a very good place to people watch and have a great time

We accidentally discovered this place. It was a nice afternoon walks. They have all you can find in any chinatown. They sold the traditional chinese medicine too which is interesting. It's nice for photoshoot, maybe. Not sure if it's cheap or expensive because we didn't stop in any shop.

I'm glad that the travel agency included Chinatown in our Singapore tour. I enjoyed the trip to the Chinese museum, as well as dining at an authentic Chinese restaurant. This place is great for buying souvenirs. Lots of cheap finds here.
Chinese New Year preparation in Chinatown. This place is well maintained, the buildings design are irresistibly cute. :)

It's really nice if you are travelling with friends who loves bargains. It's a clean chinatown. You will enjoy the selection of restaurants, stalls selling nicnacs, souvenirs, etc. a budget prices. Come and check this out. Make sure you wear your walking shoes because there's a lot to see.

REVIEW_TITLE: Nice place to visit and shop
REVIEW_BODY: China town was may favourite destination in singapore. You can find many kind oriental goods for souvenir. Just like singapore street market, they give us a reasonable price. Be awere pick pocket, for good reason put your back pack in front side.
We had fun with our three children (10, 8, 7) on Chinese New Year wandering the streets of Chinatown, searching for bargains. The people watching is fun!
This is an amazing place for shopping souvenirs for friends at a good price. The place is filled with stuff and eaterias. Tourist would love this place.
Truly felt like I was in a market in Beijing. Some shops just sell replica things but if you look carefully you can find some very interesting Chinese shops. Haven for Chinese food lovers.

This is a great area of Singapore, very colorful, specially at night. Hundreds of shops and very good prices (you can bargain). Great place to buy souvenirs and presents for friends.
The place is packed with restaurants, all you could imagine to eat at very reasonable prices.
The Buddha Tooth Relic Temple shouldn't be missed.

REVIEW_TITLE: Touristy, but some streets are really nice
REVIEW_BODY:
Center of Chinatown (Temple & Pagoda Streets) is extremely touristy and not much interesting - unless it is the first one in your life
But if you veer to Kong Saik and Ann Siang streets you can find nicely restored Chinese houses and good atmosphere. I recommend walk alongside channel between Kong Saik and Bukit Pasoh - all of the sudden you find greenery & peace
For true local feeling it is better to go to Geylang...
Truly colourful china town. Lot of mouth watering dishes at affordable prices. Make sure what's in before hog in. Other than that lot of souvenir collectives.

REVIEW_TITLE: A great place to take the family
REVIEW_BODY: Crowded when we visited, around Christmas, but a great place to spend an afternoon with the family wandering along and soaking up the atmosphere while browsing the souvenir stores, tailors, market stalls, food stalls and restaurants. Wonderful sights, sounds, colours and smells! The vendors are friendly and the bargaining is FUN! Also, the Tin Tin shop was a hit with my sons.

You get those small souvenirs at a very cheap price. The place also has a " Tintin Shop". The street side authentic Chinese food aroma surrounds the place. You also get free wi- fi :-). Many items are available there which one would love to pick up.

First time been to Chinatown on the eve of Chinese New Year. If you would like to feel how Chinatown festive feel, eve of Chinese New Year is a good day to come. You will see mountain of human and a lot of CNY snack and cookies selling there. There are some special performance too. Normal day of Chinatown, you probably won't see something like this
Need to see the china town for good restaurants and having fun with family. Very good time we had and will cherish it.

Chinatown was buzzing with atmospher no matter whether you went there day or night. Loved all the markets and food was spectacular! Wish I'd had more time there and loved all the wonder Chinese New Year decorations
if you aren't from china, do visit it. This is also a place to visit in evening , try the food and hawker market and the price of everything is pretty low, compared to city/
Definitely not a 'must' see. If you have spare time check it out. Not overly cheap. Better at night when it is cooler.

If you are into visiting Chinatowns of the world, come here too :) Came here during Chinese New Year day and was very crowded as expected. Lots of stalls selling souvenirs and little items while the restaurants are full.

The atmosphere is good though and full of New Year atmosphere with decorations filling up the place. The buildings are historical as well. I would recommend visiting here for the "feel" of the place rather than the stores for sure.
Great place to spend the day. Food halls are quite an experience and very cheap if you like to eat as the locals do. Good money changing booth in the main department store too.

REVIEW_TITLE: Not to be missed while in Singapore..
REVIEW_BODY: No two Chinatowns are exactly the same anywhere in the world..depending on the origin of the early provincial Chinese settlers..that would lend itself to the distinct type of "Chinatown ambiance"..in Singapore, the influence would be more of Hokkien, Hainanese origins rather than Cantonese..Interesting place to experience a hint of societal history of old Singapore..albeit it's a far cry from those truly days of yesteryears..Definitely, worth a visit..especially during the Chinese Lunar New Year season..
You can find various delicious food & cheap souvenirs here. You can find the free wifi too in this area

Decorations for the Chinese New Year, year of the monkey, were being put up at the time of our visit. Colours were amazing and the stalls and shops were full of life and colour along with great prices for clothing and knick knacks.

REVIEW_TITLE: The day before Lunar New Year
REVIEW_BODY: There're lots of people and lots of shop. Its very touristy. But nothing much happening. I'm a bit disappointed since I'm expecting much more.

I think this might be the best Chinatown (outside of China)I have been to. Lots of fun and things to see. Great food, get some chili crab. Shop in the street market. We were there for Chinese New Year too. It was amazing and crazy and worth going despite the crowds.
We during Chinese New Year...so much food to eat and amazing decorations. Not sure how it is the rest of the year but we really enjoyed ourselves.

REVIEW_TITLE: Don't miss it on Lunar New Year's Eve
REVIEW_BODY: We loved strolling through Chinatown during the day, but our highlight was a visit on Chinese New Year's Eve - what a crowd. Enjoy the food on food street and all the business that surrounds it.

I have always loved going to Chinatown since young, because there's lots of interesting chinese cultural stuff to look at. Especially during Chinese New Year period. The place is getting more commercial, but there's always the Chinese cultural aspects to look at. Worth looking to see traditions and modernity blending together.
Love the decoration this year!!! ^^ The feel for Chinese New Year is so overwhelming! It's suitable for the whole family outing. Yay!!
chinatown is very beautiful and sellers are kindly.but in contrast to chinatown in kuala lumpur here the goods relatively expensive.I love here and advise to tourists which go there and visit.

REVIEW_TITLE: Chinatown is great in any city but especially Singapore
REVIEW_BODY: Loved the shops no one really bothered you. Went to a restaurant there and had a great lunch! Lots to see and do just loved it and don't miss it!

REVIEW_TITLE: Lunar New Year visit to Chinatown
REVIEW_BODY:
Chinatown, being a heritage, site charms foreigners with its conservation houses, 5 foot ways and food. If you would like to imagine what Singapore was like in the early 1930s to 1950s, you could catch a little historical glimpse of the place. It is quite similar to the streets of Malacca and Georgetown in Penang in Malaysia.

It has been a while, since I last went to Chinatown, apart from satisfying the occasional dim sum craving. Hence, being able to visit Chinatown again was an experience.

The lunar new year festivities bring crowds from other parts of Singapore to this otherwise touristy area of Singapore. Red Lanterns, decorations, fake firecrackers, red packets throng the streets a few weeks before the Lunar New Year. The festive carnivals boast of Lunar New Year Cookies, crackers, pineapple tarts, oranges and candies to tease your tastebuds. I bought a container of seaweed crackers at $12 and a small little bottle of prawn rolls at $6. I wouldn't say it is a bargain but the taste was rather decent. My past experience buying lots of cookies in Chinatown was disappointing, hence the I did not buy too much this time. You could buy better tasting goodies at the bazaars of the shopping malls.

I went to Chinatown on a Friday morning to early noon and there were many preschoolers visiting Chinatown, as part of their excursion and learning experience. There was occasional rain and drizzle and it was a pain to have to seek shelter in the crowd. Even with a small, lightweight stroller, it was difficult to manoeuvre through the crowd and the humidity was not helping, especially for the 1.5 year old little one. He was restless and uncomfortable. We occasionally sought respite in the air-conditioned shops and not surprisingly, these shops offer better bargains than the pasar malam (bazaar) shops. I suspect the rent for the bazaar is very high, hence transferring the costs to the consumers.

You would have thought bargaining should be easy for a local but I never liked haggling. It is difficult and sometimes there might be miscommunication and you might not get the price you think is reasonable. However, I managed to get a lunar new year suit for my son at $17 (fixed price) at one of the shops. It is of decent quality but I was not able to bargain a single dime off. Having said that, some of the shops had lovely cheongsams (little dresses for girls) at SGD$10. It was a good bargain but it did not come in the right size for my 3 year old.

I also bought some pretty tissue box holders at (2 for $5) and a table runner for $6.90. I would say these are decent buys.

Overall, Chinatown is an interesting place. The weather might be better in the evenings but I suspect the place would be very crowded when people get off work and do their last minute shopping. Expect more crowds this Lunar New Year weekend.

On the night that we visited Chinatown there was some sort of special event on and it was basically impossible to move anywhere without being carried away in a sea of people. We asked the taxi driver on the way back to the hotel and he said that it had something to do with Chinese New Year even though new year was still a month away. I have heard many good things about Chinatown in the past and would love to return when it is not so busy so as to experience the many wonderful things that it has to offer,

We rode the bus in front of Ibis Hotel. The streets were full of people shopping for Chinese New Year. Everyone was excited to buy stuff like bakwa or pork meat, fruits, trinkets and charms for luck. Such busy streets!

Visited Chinatown one night after getting off from the MRT. Had a dinner for a wayside eatery of Original noodles & prawn. The street was teeming with many tourists and the whole street was filled by them & eating places, Didnt shop.
Chinatown is famous by food and souvenir. Many people find for cheap souvenirs here. You can bargain with seller here. Make sure you get a cheap price

I went to ChinaTown to try their food and experience the boutiques inside the compound, upon arriving I noticed that the location is spacious and the parking space was big enough for tourists and locals as well. I first went and try their food! the White Chicken with Rice was the best here.. you wouldn't need any more condiment because of its natural taste. foods here are fresh! then I went to the boutiques, they have so many stuffs but i bought too many in Bugis already so I decided not to buy anything there anymore and it is quite expensive too. but this is where locals and travelers meet so I suggest you try to visit this area.

REVIEW_TITLE: Dynamic, Colorful, but not so different from the rest of Singapore
REVIEW_BODY: Sure, it is colorful, vibrant, has a great atmosphere, and all that. But the whole point of a Chinatown is to re-create a mini-China in a foreign land. Considering that Singapore is mainly Chinese anyway, it doesn't come as something very different. Not a must-see attraction (unless there is a major Chinese festival), but you an pass through on your way to some other attraction like the Harbourfront.

We try and avoid the Chinatown main walkways that are filled with the usual tourist trinkets but instead seek out some of the wonderful restaurants down the side streets. If you do the Food Street thing, avoid 6pm to 8pm and go after that. You will get a table and get your food quicker.

Chinatown is one of the most busy part of Singapore. Nowadays the Chinatown is getting bigger, including the surroundings.
Here we can see chinese heritage culture in Singapore, also can see famous Sri Mariaman Temple.
We can also find and buy souvenirs.
Food food and food... Culinary journey along the road.
It is a very complete place and you can find almost anything you need here.
Unfortunately in some spot, not so clean.

We did a guided tour on a double decker bus in the evening so whilst we didnt spend much time in china town itself we got to see the spectacular lights that were on display for chinese new year. There was beautiful architecture in chinatown and the smells from the market were amazing. I strongly recommend visiting chinatown!

Chinatown one of the best place to buy a key chain, t shirt or any singapore souvenirs or gifts.. you can see that this place has a colourful hanging lantern. My tips, don't forget to take a selfie :)

Pretty much just another Chinatown, but none the less worth the visit and a look. Lots of shops, some cheap and nasty but a variety of all sorts and good restaurants to choose from. There wasn't a lot happening at the time of day we visited (morning), but preparations for Chinese New Year were underway so perhaps there would have been more excitement / entertainment at night.
Totally enjoyed it. We took our time and went into most of the shops, and brought a lot of items to take home. Kids enjoyed it. Would do again

I thought I'd find this place to be filled with cheap, loud coloured things. Very far from it! It's a huge place! Lots of interesting merchandise to offer. It was clean. Lots of food options. Visitors will be spoiled for choices with regards to souvenirs to take back home.

REVIEW_TITLE: a flavor of china in singapore
REVIEW_BODY: nice place for shopping, clean place and cheap items, but very crowded coz chinese new year is soon! food were all delicous! i like the mee goreng food in sinagpore spicy and yummy!

REVIEW_TITLE: Worth a look but watch the chillies
REVIEW_BODY: Chinese New Year very busy but spectacular with the light and lanterns. Worth having a bite and a look. Watch out for those festy chillies they can be hazardous to your health. Easy to get a cab the cabs are cheap here

I have been here for a while and really, it is not as great as many tourists and Singaporeans say it is.

Honestly, mostly I find most things in Chinatown do not stand out It is nice enough, especially at this time of year, but after walking (following the wife and kids) around for a bit it becomes boring.

OK, probably I am not good at shopping.

REVIEW_TITLE: Night time visit during New Year celebrations
REVIEW_BODY:
We visited the bustling street markets of Chinatown during the New Year Celebrations and the atmosphere was great.

There are many souvenirs and other goods available, but it was the food stalls I found most interesting. From the smoked goods (sausages, ducks, chicken) to the fruit, nuts and seeds - it was a sight to see.

You do need to be aware of pickpockets and there are plenty of warning signs - I did encounter a person who sidled up to me and tried - but had nothing in my pockets and was conscious of him there and on loudly 'hay'-ing him, he quickly moved away. My teenage kids were a bit more concerned after that. As the signs say, so keep hold of your bags and keep them in front of you.

Apart from that, our night trip to Chinatown, with all of the Year of the Monkey lighting, was wonderful and definitely worth seeing.

The infrastructure here is dominantly Chinese (from the name should be explanation enough). The Sri Mariamman temple sticks out quite unexpectedly though. Also good if you wanna buy Chinese food cheaply and souvenirs. But to be honest for me, the area was a bit boring.

REVIEW_TITLE: Very Touristy, but worth a visit
REVIEW_BODY: A riot of noise, smells and colour. We have been here many times, this time with my sister and brother-in-law to show the must do sites of Singapore. Worth the visit for the atmosphere, but would come every time I came to Singapore.

I am not fond of tourist places but in Chinatown it brings a whole new meaning of turning back the clock. Things are cheap in Chinatown - I initially went to People's Park centre to make glasss, VG opticals are one of the cheapest and most reliable optical shops. Next door s Chinatown that has a feel and warmth of Chinese hospitality. A place not to be mssd.

Visited a few times on our recent visit to Singapore. Very crowded on a Sunday afternoon, but great atmosphere. Lots of shops selling everything imaginable. No drainage in the streets so can get a lot of water when it rains. At the end of the stalls is Smith Street Hawker Centre, which is touristy, but excellent. Also, drop into the tourist information centre for maps, advice, tickets etc. They are very helpful. The is a food court with over 230 stalls at the end of Chinatown, upstairs. Very cheap food, geared towards locals. Downstairs, men sit and play Chess and other games under the shade of the trees. Well worth a visit, lots to see in this area. The MRT station brings you straight out into Chinatown.

REVIEW_TITLE: Place that everyone Must go and see
REVIEW_BODY: The Chinatown is one of many attractions in Singapore that everyone must go and see. There are so many food stall with various Chinese food. There are also many shops that sell various items such as fabrics, food, souvenirs, and so much more. There is a big buddha Temple there.

REVIEW_TITLE: Love seeing Chinatown precincts wherever we go
REVIEW_BODY: We love seeing Chinatown precincts wherever we go and the Singapore one is fantastic. Lots of shops and stalls to explore and great food to sample. Can get crowded but that is part of the fun.

REVIEW_TITLE: its very attractive and good street for shopper!!!!!!!!!
REVIEW_BODY: its has very pleasant whether and good and happy environment for shoppers china town means u get all the stuff regarding chopstick etc very cheap very instresting stuff and good quality stuff I will recommend this sight for shopping lovers!!!!!!!!!
Enjoyed wandering though the stalls and the hustle and bustle of Chinatown. Definitely worth a visit. Lots to see. Had enjoyable meal there and beer well priced.

REVIEW_TITLE: Chinatown with flavour ~ eat well and very cheap
REVIEW_BODY:
Singapore is quite cosmopolitan with a vast number of different cultures co-existing but obviously dominant Chinese population.
Typical Chinatown setup but the food is amazing and it is was Singapore is renowned for and the Hawker setup is just teaming with locals all lining up to get the best noodles, fishball soup and dumplings they can get their hands on for very small cost. I fed family of four for AUD15. I love this place and will revisit for the quality not just the minimal cost.

Chinatown wasn't my favourite place to be. It was very hot (seemed hotter than City Central) and there were things that they were serving up at Cafe's and Restaurants that you forever want to block out of your head. Its not for everyone, but i am sure there are some people that would love it here. It is also easy to access via the MRT as Chinatown is a station itself.

Interesting walk through narrow streets with old houses and many shops selling all sorts of wares. Enjoyed foot massage and warm water foot soak here, perfect after walking around. plenty of places to eat and relax but be aware it can get very busy.

REVIEW_TITLE: Clean with a large choice of foods
REVIEW_BODY: China Town has been cleaned up alot since my last visit in 2014. There are the usual cheap flea market type of goods to purchase however we preferred to taste the various traditional types of cuisine. It was fantastic. Definately worth the visit.

REVIEW_TITLE: A must see whilst in Singapore.
REVIEW_BODY: Plenty of stall holders wanting to sell their wares. Well worth a visit. Chinatown is very popular with tourists and well patronised by the locals. Food is cheap and the meals are good.

REVIEW_TITLE: Great place to shop and relax
REVIEW_BODY: China town is easy to get to on the MRT. The station entrance is in the market itself. This is a great place to buy cheap but good souvenirs that will cost more in other parts of Singapore. There are many food and drink options here which is definitely required when shopping.

Chinatown is always an impressive area to walk through. its a must visit area. Good food outlets here too. good area to find Tailors and souvenirs. Dont forget to bargain, its not shameful, they expect you to and you will get a good deal.

Searching for great bargains on things you never thought even existed? Chinatown is the place you want to go! Walking out of the Chinatown MRT, you arrive straight in the heart of a bustling street market, full of tourists and Singaporeans alike. We walked down the street until we got to Smith Street, which is considered Chinatown's 'Food Street'. Taking a right turn we headed to Chinatown Food Complex which is pretty much invisible from afar, as it just looks like a car park building. But it is a foodcourt - the biggest in Singapore apparently - and sells the usual items of food at the usual low prices. On our way back to the MRT, we ventured into many of the stalls and bought a few knick knacks to take home as souvenirs.

REVIEW_TITLE: The place for local food and affordable price
REVIEW_BODY: If you are looking for Chinese food, this is the good place for you. With the variety of food you may choose and share the food with your family or friends. The portion they offer is enough for 2 persons. Will be a bit crowded when it's lunch or dinner time. Most people will queue in the kind of noodle or seafood stall.

REVIEW_TITLE: A great place to stroll around and be entertained by the variety on display
REVIEW_BODY: A good place to visit. Give yourself half a day to stroll around the multiple shops offering typical trinkets and trash but also some real unique pieces, Great place to have a bite to eat and people watch.

We did a tour which included a walking tour around chinatown a meal and then some free time to roam the markets followed by a rickshaw ride and then a bumboat ride from Clarke quay down the river to the marina to see the lights and sounds of Singers at night. whole thing was great value and a heap of fun

What else do you expect? It's cheap, it's hot, it's sultry. It has good food for most (vegetarians & vegans not so much) we stopped by to visit The tooth relic temple. It was hot & super hot in January so not sure if I'd ever go in summer!!
But the stuff available for shopping to take back home!! Man, this is the place.
Cheap & quite a selection offered.
Price is cheaper than Bugis; more variations - there's even a Tintin Store; a lot of food too and less crowded.

I wish we had gone here earlier.
This is one month before the Chinese New Year and it's so much decorations all over the place.
A lot of food places and small shops!
Really good food and really cheap if you compare to the rest of Singapore!
Very rude sellers. Low quality goods. Chinese market in Kuala Lumpur is way better . Very wide space take too much time in walking. Maybe good for souvenirs

REVIEW_TITLE: Worth a visit and great food
REVIEW_BODY: We took taxi to China town to experience the atmosphere and spent a very pleasant couple of hours eating in one of the many restaurants on the main food hall street with the food being excellent. Its worth taking insect repellent with you as my son was bitten a couple of times. The market was interesting and if you are in Singapore its a great place to spend a couple of hours,
Lots to see in Chinatown, old and new... Locals going about their business, all sorts of restaurants and hotels of all sorts...
If you want to do cheap nick nack shopping this is the place. Was good to have a look and buy your cheap little souvenirs. We did the Chinatown tour which was good.

Lots of gifts available. Pashminas are great, haggle but $18 cheapest for good quality.if you get them cheaper then well done. Lots of clothes for kids. Stalls are open by 9am so good for a quick look. Otherwise evening markets at Bugis is good for $5 watches and cheap T Shirts. Happy shopping.

Chinatown has a gorgeous Buddest temple on Bridge street definitely worth visiting, a great way to introduce Chinese culture to pre-schoolers +. The Chinese styled temple is spectacular both externally and internally.

Stall after stall of cheap overpriced Singaporean and Chinese memorabilia, good food if you do your research or are lucky and a rich history
Do yourself a favour and get on a tour else all you'll see is the stalls of trinkets and some nice buildings, but you'll lack insight and understanding.
We lived just bedside China Town! Plenty of stores&food!the kids loved to see around and looking all the China souvenirs!
You can spend half a day wondering around Chinatown and there are some bargains to be had that you will not find elsewhere. Food is delicious and well priced

As every major city worldwide seems to have a Chinatown, this was just another one to tick off. I came here to look for keyrings, which were, on the most part, no cheaper than anywhere else, however I did grab 6 for $2SGD at a local shop which was a good deal. We also ate here, in the Hong Lim Market complex. The food was inexpensive however it was not very nice; just something for if you're on a budget and in a rush.
We didn't see anything special here so I would only recommend visiting the area if you happen to be passing by, otherwise it's not really a negative if you don't see it.
Lots of delicious food stalls and shops to be found here as well as beautiful architecture and historical monuments.
Yep, great day. Loads going on, various food budget options & plenty of shops & market stalls to choose from. Very handy from MRT station.

Our visit was during the Chinese New Year celebration and it was absolute insanity, busy, people everywhere...and we absolutely loved it! Bought a beautiful piece of art there to take home with us to the states. Was about $70 SGP, but something so unique. You can get items like that all the way down to cheap trinkets. We also ate dinner here, although I couldn’t tell you the name of the restaurant, but it was so delicious, service was good, and prices were reasonable. Been to several chinatowns in different areas of the world and this one was my favorite by a mile!

Since it’s the lead up to the Chinese New Year, Chinatown was chaos which I thoroughly enjoyed. Plenty of market stalls selling souvenirs and other tat. Nice example of Chinese culture in the area as well.

There was a lot to see and do in Chinatown. There were a lot of vendors selling souvenirs and food. The food is reasonably price. We went there both day and night and found day time the best time to go. Night time gets way too crowded.

REVIEW_TITLE: A real taste of the orient
REVIEW_BODY: The whole area is a good destination for anyone.from food to shops a must. Set prices but still cheap enough to make it worth the trip. Food was great and service was good.if you have time.as all markets your told to be aware of pick pockets.same all over the world

Our visit to Singapore was the start of a months long travel.

No matter what you want be it a hotel, food and drink, trinkets, T-shirt’s, hand made clothing, cameras down to a pedicure you will find it within Chinatown.

There are plenty of knock offs available but the terms has two meanings firstly a good copy of a brand item such as a go pro camera and comes with full international warrantee and secondly an item which is made to be an look a like copy of the original and you will be lucky if it will last a few months.

A majority of the food we tasted was wonderful and reasonably priced. If you look at the size of some of the kitchens visible as you walk a long the street you do wonder how they can produce so many disks in a kitchen the size of cloakroom in the UK with just a couple of burners.

International beers are available but the local tiger beer is ever bit as good and cheaper.

REVIEW_TITLE: Best Chinatown I have ever seen
REVIEW_BODY: The area is so large and vibrant. Easy to get too and full of traditional. The food and market stalls fantastic. It is the only Chinatown in the world with 5 different religious temples.
This really is a great place to shop and enjoy excellent food and some Tiger Beer. Plenty to do and see also it is safe, like most of Singapore.

One of the most happening areas of Singapore for inexpensive food, culture and some beautiful architecture , no trip to Singapore is complete without a visit. We Loved the Grilled Stingray at a good stall called Yummy King.
Bustling Chinatown is great to see but it is the amazing food that cannot be beaten with so much variety and such reasonable prices you feel like you are living the real Singapore
China town is the same in everyplace we go, this one is very large with a lot of variety so if you want to shop and experience some local food this is the place. Bring a hat and some walking shoes.
Lots of great food in Chinatown. Also lots of porcelain shops and souvenir shops here. 2 MRT lines meet here. The Blue and the Purple lines.

Heaps of markets and shops with plenty of bargains Best to have a wander through first as there are a lot selling similar products for a lot cheaper than other shops in the same area. Great to pick up cheap souvenirs for family

Really nice place but the lack of English with some vendors means you won't always be served or understood so be patient. Lots of quirky things to see and buy - great gifts here too - but lots of durian!
Very very singular place in centre of Singapore. Too many shops, souvenirs and topical products from China! Karaoke and dance on the street...you can think to be in China!

You can find about anything your heart would desire in Chinatown. It was a great place for us to pick up some souvenirs while in Singapore and we thoroughly enjoyed walking through it. The people watching was awesome, the food was amazing and I highly recommend you check it out!

REVIEW_TITLE: Nice photo ops and cheaper goods
REVIEW_BODY: Can get very busy in the evenings. Good photo ops and cheaper goods although quality may not be great. Lot of cheap eats around too.
How can you not visit this amazing place. Loads of fabulous places to eat authentic food. So easy to get around and very safe .

By day it is a fairly simple Chinese market selling the usual tourist tat. But come here at night and it transforms! Once the cooking stations get going and the place is viewed with all the neon lights etc. its like visiting old world china.
There’s a very unusual temple that’s worth a visit. A Chinese cultural heritage center also worth calling in and across the road there is an indoor food court if it starts raining.
Not very large but worth visiting

This appeared to be a large marketplace selling the same cheap items and there was no real sense of China unlike London Chinatown. Some of the food options looked interesting but we didnt use any. At the Southern end is a large open square where locals play board games but there is a large indoor market. Worth going downstairs to the food market which is an interesting walk around especially fish and fresh veggie sections.

Over the past twenty years I have been here many here times. Food, shopping culture chinatown has it all. There is so much choice for food hawker centers or restaurants. Lots of shopping temples including a hindu temple. Recently there have been a lot of new murals which are very good. The last few years it has got very touristy with a lot more bars and drinking, big crowds at the weekend.

REVIEW_TITLE: More food than you could want
REVIEW_BODY: There are hundreds or appears to be...places you can eat and drink. The atmosphere in the area comes alive as the sun goes down. We went for dinner one evening snd really enjoyed it. Worth jumping on the mrt Train and visiting chinatown.
Chinatown is a must when visiting Singapore, vibrant area with loads of restuarants, bars and street food vendors which are great value and food is great too, easy to get to using mrt
Chinatown is Singapore is fantastic for shopping. My wife and I spent several nights wandering through the market stalls and looking at souvenirs and the like. Would thoroughly recommend a visit.

Had lunch at Chinatown hawker stalls then strolled in and out of streets. Lots of souvenir and everything else you can imagine here. Can’t believe all these places stay in business. There are so many different stalls yet they all sell similar items. Definitely worth spending a few hours and getting some food.
Very interesting to see and wander through the streets. There are lots of shops selling cheap goods. Also lots of cheap places to eat.

Singapore is definitely not a cheap city but Chinatown provides lots of delicious cheap eats. The MRT station is very close by so it’s easy to break up a day’s sightseeing with a tasty cheap lunch. Well worth a visit.
Wow! This is a must visit for your holiday bargains and souvenirs. There are a good variety of shops but prices do vary so be prepared shop around?!
This has to be one of those you MUST visit. Daytime is fine but night time you get the atmosphere. The smell of all the different foods is unbelievable.

REVIEW_TITLE: Great place to walk around and get a sense of old Singapore
REVIEW_BODY: Many lanes full of restaurants, vendors selling souvenirs, etc. this was a great place to walk. We enjoyed poking around to see what we could find.
We enjoyed every minute of walking around in Chinatown. Great food and drink and the local population were super friendly too. Great shopping as well.

REVIEW_TITLE: Every city has a China Town
REVIEW_BODY: All China Towns all over the world are as lively and vibrant as this one. Lots to see and eat. Follow the locals at other markets for the best deals.

REVIEW_TITLE: Best China Town outside of Australia
REVIEW_BODY: Great place for interesting items to buy! Have fun haggling and there’s some nice street food up the middle of Food Street. Really friendly and I will be going back👍
Admit we only drove through on the hop on hop off bus was not interested in getting off and walking. Why would you. Interesting to drive through that is about it.
We took part in a hawker walking tour great food and very informative. We also visited the Chinese heritage centre which brought the past back to life

The area is great to immerse yourself in that local experience especially with the cuisine. You get a variety of local food stalls- all clean and affordable. It’s a busy area with quite a bit of hustle and bustle but definitely a must visit.
Great place to grab a few bargains and soak up the wonderful atmosphere. Everyone was cheerful and helpful - great way to spend the afternoon.

Chinatown, did exactly what it said on the tin! Great food for good prices. Nice shopping. Good bars. A lot less hassle from shop owners etc than we were imagining. Around the smelly fruits (in my opinion)!!!!!!!

So much to see and explore between the stalls, street vendors, foods and temples. And unlike Little India, we found Chinatown to be easier to walk and not nearly as crowded. There's the usual cheap souvenirs being hawked in a number of stores but it's more than that, and you'll see a lot of locals as well, which speaks to it's authenticity.

Did a free walking tour through Indie Singapore. So much to see. Oh tour met at the MRT station and walked through China Town, stopping at temples, historic sites, through an apartment building, a Hawker Food Hall and finally the Govt building where the Department that looks after Singapore's development is housed and a full sized model of Singapore is housed. Our guide Wei is a local who gave us some insight as to how Singaporeans live. China Town is bright with lots of restaurants and souvenir shops. A place I recommend.
Loved China Town,busy it was worth the trip. Lots of stalls selling from jade to souvenirs. At a reasonable price.
Walked into Chinatown in Singapore whilst staying in city, interesting novel old buildings, shops and restaurants.

REVIEW_TITLE: A little bit of the old Singapore
REVIEW_BODY: This takes you back to the old days of Singapore. Cheap shops, tailors, lots of color and entertainment. This area is full of character and great restaurants.
Worth a wonder through but don't fret if you miss it. Good eating places but the stalls and shops just have the same things you see in all China towns.

As usual, this place is crowded especially on weekend. The crow flow in from lunch till.. ...

Buddha Tooth Relic temple is worth to visit though is crowded. Behind if this temple, you can find the big hawker center on level 2 which serve good food at reasonable price such as the fish head, grill meat and good brewery beer too. Again crowded. Indian temple is nice too if you like different culture architecture. Ang xiang hill is nice spot for night life.
To wonder around the streets & stalls is wonderful. The people’s place food court is amazing & you can get any type of food at a great price. Felt very safe & got a few bargains. Well worth a visit

REVIEW_TITLE: Great spot for souvenirs, food and temples
REVIEW_BODY:
Fabulous area for souvenirs, temples and food. Yes it's very touristy, but it's fun!!

Also be careful if you eat in Chinatown to make sure your food is piping hot... Ours was not, we ate it anyway and ended up with two rather upset stomachs the following day!!
If you’re going to Singapore make sure you visit Chinatown. Buy some curry puffs. They are excellent! Very busy place but picturesque. Well worth going
There is so much to see around Chinatown, so impressed and so many beautiful buildings and very friendly people. We spent a good few hours in this area, and would recommend visiting.
Did not enjoy china town at all. Went in the evening and expected to see it all lit up and bustling. Many restaurants were closed and the whole experience was disappointing.

Nice food in this area lovely place! We ate on a corner restaurant although the food was nice the service was a little slow! However they were busy! The sweet and sour was amazing, lemon pork ribs very nice too!

China town is oldest Chinese settlement in Singapore,good place to explore the old world charm and heritage. Buddha tooth reilc temple,though just 10 yr old is worth visit,also lots of Chinese restaurant and 2 hawker centre in the vicinity,Chinatown and Maxwell,also lots of shops for cheap savoniers.Nearest MRT Chinatown,choose the correct exit and you will be at food street just behind relic temple. There is also a south Indian temple which is worth visit.
Great experience. Good food. Lots of cheap souvenirs and some quality stuff too. Awesome street market. 👍
We are well travelled and have visited quite a few chinatowns. This was underwhelming, nothing to ride homw about.

REVIEW_TITLE: Okay to visit not what we thought
REVIEW_BODY: We only had a clod days so tried to look at a few recommended places we dust like the shopping very junky . Nothing really to buy. Food okay and plenty of options

We visisted China Town a couple of times while we was in Singapore and enjoyed it very much. We had food and drinks here which was reasonably priced and food was very tasty. Always has a good atmosphere day and night

We had a lazy afternoon strolling around chinatown..the sights and colours amazing an eyeopener with what some of the stalls selling ..yes you get a bit harrassed but politely and you just say no and walk on .
Great local food, better prices than in the centre of Singapore. Easy access through the underground. Its busy but fun!
If you want some shopping madness then go here, vast array of food halls which are always busy and food is fresh. Shopping is great too!

In many countries, Chinatown is a place that is always unique and worth visiting, full of Chinese knacks and culture, as the name suggests, where people live and gather from ethnic Chinese. Goods sold, food and types of services such as massage and fruits. This Chinatown has a place to eat that is given a hood so that we can eat without being disturbed by the heat of the sun or rain. The goods sold are also very diverse in this area of Chinese architecture, plus a store with a tagline of 1 $ no need to compare

Busy busy busy, some really authentic stalls and a walk around a stopping for something to eat, everyone very friendly and always anxious to help. One thing I did like you were not pestered into buying anything

Fun to explore the mix of tourist gift stores, food outlets and traditional religious sites. Get off train at Chinatown Station and you are at the heart of the action. Everything is within a few minutes walk. Food not as cheap as hawker centres but still pretty reasonable and popular.

The temple is beautiful when you visit at night time. However, the street around the temple is not well arrange and it normal. Only main street seem more busy and some place that you can seat to enjoy drink or take some food.
When we visited they were in the middle of the mid autumn festival. Great colour, so many different to to see. Loved the markets

Great place to get a cheap meal plenty to choose from in this Hawer market. I found it to be one of the best in Singapore Plenty of shop's to buy thing's but I was only interested in trying different Chinese dishes

This was definitely not one of the better Chinatowns we have visited. Apart from anything else it was hot and extremely smelly and there was no atmosphere at all. We decided to come back another day and started at Chinatown food street, it was around 11:00am and wasn’t as hot that day but there was still no one about and still no atmosphere. The shopping itself was pretty ordinary, we bought a few cheap souvenirs and admired some of the artwork and static displays but apart from this there wasn’t really much to do. It is however, quite pretty at night when the lights are on.
This is an interesting part of Singapore close to the Maxwell Road food centre. It's worth visiting but not a necessity.
Souvenir shops, bars, and western food all geared towards tourists. Can be quite crowded, but still a must see for the history, on your first visit to Singapore.
A step back in time with a trip through an heritage of the past. Very easy to go there with one of the underground stations right at the quarter entrance

REVIEW_TITLE: A feast of food and shopping
REVIEW_BODY: We were amazed at the sights and sounds of Chinatown, there are an abundance of restaurant's and shops, there are some really good bargains to be had, lots of Chinese souvenirs at really good prices, and then there's the restaurant's and outside eating, there's no way your going hungry. We ate at the Maxwell food court, very friendly and very reasonably priced.

Looking at the reviews,people have had mixed reactions to Chinatown but we loved it.The atmosphere is great,yes,you do have to know the price of things to know if you’re getting a bargain.We were offered items at “ cheap prices” that in actual fact we could buy in Brisbane.Having said that,we still got some nice souvenirs and good buys ,visited the temple ...which was amazing ..and ate a nice meal.Yes,the food hall was crowed and no frills but we wanted to eat where the locals went ,not at a restaurant.
All in all ,a really enjoyable ,but hot,so hot day.

You can try a million kind of food and drink. Or buy souvenirs. We went on a free walking tour by Monster tour with Bas, that’s why it was more interesting! Also we tried in the market the food what called Popiah, if you can, try it!

REVIEW_TITLE: Vibrant area with bargains available at the night market
REVIEW_BODY:
I would recommending visiting China Town at night when the night markets are in full swing.

There are lots of bargains available, including tourist memorabilia and clothing.

Interspersed amongst the markets are some beautiful temples - tourists are free to wander into the temples and take pictures if they wish.

There are also a large number of eating options - from eat on the street quick Chinese food to more upmarket options.

Well worth a visit during your time in Singapore.
You can get all your souvenir stuff from here for cheap. Great area to walk about and explore. Lots of shops and restaurants.

Always vibrant and colorful you get drawn in by the glitz and friendly though sometimes persistent sales people. Loads of bargain souvenirs to be had. Located with great eateries around to rest and recoup between shopping.

So much to see, hear and observe! Watch your step as you might step on some food. Food is everywhere you look. Cultural Heritage Center is a must, otherwise just sit somewhere with a drink and observe!
Street hawker, pawn shop, chinese chess, etc. Enjoy every moments strolling around eating local foods.
